key_points: Tiger Woods mistakenly thought he was in Florida during a hospital interview following his February car crash in Los Angeles.
Woods' blood pressure was too low to administer pain medication after the crash.
An empty pharmaceutical bottle was found at the crash scene.
Vehicle data indicates Woods was going straight with no steering input detected until late in the crash sequence.
The crash was caused by Woods driving at a speed unsafe for the road conditions and his inability to negotiate a curve.
Woods was traveling over 82 mph in a 45-mph zone and applied the gas pedal at 99% just before the crash.
There was no evidence of braking or steering to avoid the crash, leading to speculation Woods might have been unconscious.
Investigators found no reason to believe Woods was impaired by alcohol or drugs at the time of the crash.
The report describes Woods as 'somewhat combative' post-crash, attributed to the trauma and shock from his injuries.
This is Woods' third driving incident since 2009, with previous incidents including a careless driving citation and a DUI arrest.
spokespersons: Sergeant Michael Downing (author of the data report)
Jonathan Cherney (former police detective, forensic crash reconstruction expert)
Sheriff Alex Villanueva (Los Angeles County Sheriff)
